author: af77
content:
Hi Kevaundray ðŸ‘‹ 

> Can an attacker generate a false proof to extract value, then take 80% from the pool?
Yes, the bond pool wouldn't stop them from being able to make false proofs, just tempt them to reveal their knowledge of Tau. 

> `Value of Bonded ETH pool > Value of generating false proofs` Is this possible if the value of generating a false proof means extracting value from Ethereum?
This is a really interesting question. Even thinking about this for a few minutes I'm not sure. Could you elaborate on this a bit more? 

> If I were to obtain tau in a non-trivial way, I would probably not alert anyone as the value of generating a false proof in the future may be worth more than what is currently in the pool. Even moreso, if I can do it without detection (I don't know if this is the case)
Yes, if the value of knowing Tau and exploiting it with fake proofs exceeds the payout they could collect from the bond pool an attacker would choose to hold their knowledge of Tau. Perhaps one way to counter this dynamic is to have the bond pool start very high value but then slowly unlock back to the stakers over time. If the attacker knows Tau they would be incentivized to cash in quickly.

Example:  Bond pool starts at $200 million, and will linearly decrease in value over 2 years to zero.

author: af77
content:
> In this example, the attacker has extracted value by using a fake proof and they have taken 80% from the bond pool. This seems like the logical way to do it, instead of taking from the pool first and alerting everyone
Yep that'd be the highest paying way to attack, however in the event the fake proof was detected the bond pool could have a kill switch to immediately disable the attacker from withdrawing using Tau. That way if the attacker wanted to generate fake proofs, they risk losing access to the bond pool if discovered.

author: af77
content:
> Its possible to do it orthogonally to the ceremony, though I am not convinced that it would solve the problem of an attacker knowing tau. 
Bond pool wouldn't be for stopping the attacker from knowing Tau, that's the job of the ceremony.

author: af77
content:
> It may open us up to additional problems, like what if the contract holding the bond gets hacked or someone figures out a way to extract value without tau (making us think that we need to redo the ceremony)
Yes, this would add an additional point of failure, we'd need to consider if the potential benefits outweigh the risks. They may not.

author: af77
content:
> This is also under the assumption that an attacker who has obtained tau's main motivation will be monetary. 
I don't think this is true. If an attacker intended to use Tau to fake a proof for a purpose that is non-monetary in nature, but then is faced with a choice that they could instead withdraw the Bond pool instead, they could weigh the value between the non-monetary and monetary rewards. If they thought the risk to being caught was high enough and they could instead walk away with the Bond pool, it may tempt them to take the money and let people know Tau is known.
